title: Hyperscale Data Bitcoin Treasury at 97.5% of Market Capitalization at Approximately $75.5 Million - Financial Times
snippet: ### Hyperscale Data Bitcoin Treasury at 97.5% of Market Capitalization at Approximately $75.5 Million. ***Company Holds 498.4633 Bitcoin and has Allocated $31.5 Million of Cash for Future Purchases of Bitcoin***. (NYSE American: GPUS), an artificial intelligence ("**AI**") data center company anchored by Bitcoin ("**Hyperscale Data**" or the "**Company**"), today announced that its Bitcoin treasury, including current holdings and cash allocated to committed purchases of Bitcoin, totaled approximately $75.5 million, based on the price of Bitcoin as of December 14, 2025. The Company remains committed to its long-term goal of accumulating Bitcoin equal to 100% of its market capitalization as part of its broader $100 milliondigital asset treasury ("**DAT**") strategy. In addition, Hyperscale Data has allocated $31.5 million of cash for Sentinum to deploy into open-market Bitcoin purchases. "Reaching 97.5% of the market capitalization is a significant milestone for the Company," stated Milton "Todd" Ault III, Executive Chairman of Hyperscale Data. Hyperscale Data will fully deploy the cash allocated to its DAT strategy into Bitcoin purchases over time.

title: From Wild West To Wall Street: Blockchain Founders Redefine Trust - Forbes
snippet: The global blockchain technology market is forecast to hit $72 billion by 2027 - proof of expanding institutional confidence and demand for regulated deployment. Increasingly, institutional deployments depend on such systems, with design that builds in compliance. The business solves issues at the heart of traditional blockchain enterprise design briefs: regulatory collision across conflicting legal territories and catastrophic integration across legacy systems. LimeChain prioritizes audit, compliance and integration before development - selling banks, governments and asset managers risk reduction as a product. It’s a translation of blockchain’s raw potential into a format that institutions can deploy under regulator-grade expectations. Second, enterprises fear that blockchain deployments will break multiple existing systems just to install one new one. Most enterprises do not yet employ enough internal blockchain engineers to scale independently once systems are delivered. The company’s most visible proof point arrived with Project Diamond, a custom institutional asset platform engineered by LimeChain for Coinbase Asset Management inside the Abu Dhabi Global Market regulatory sandbox.

title: The Untold Story of Dmitry Saksonov: From Isolation to Inspiration - Latin Times
snippet: # The Untold Story of Dmitry Saksonov: From Isolation to Inspiration. For Dmitry Saksonov, that moment came in 2018. Out of that conviction, the idea for Blockchain Sports began to form. From that promise, Blockchain Sports took shape. The vision was bold: connect athletes, fans, and clubs directly through blockchain and artificial intelligence. By 2023, Blockchain Sports had grown rapidly, employing more than 1,500 people. What emerged from that reset was not just a company, but an infrastructure for the future of sport. Blockchain Sports built two football academies in Brazil with IoT-based training systems, launched Atleta Network, its proprietary Layer-1 blockchain, and developed AI tools to evaluate athletic performance in real time. In February 2024, Blockchain Sports made its global debut at Dubai's Coca-Cola Arena. For Saksonov, the moment carried personal weight. Today, the company is valued at more than $250 million, and its next chapter—Blockchain Sports Arena—is set to connect three billion fans and 300,000 clubs through gamified engagement and blockchain-driven loyalty systems.

title: Medicine approval times in Europe to be cut by almost 15% - The Pharmaceutical Journal
snippet: The Council of the European Union said that planned changes to European pharmaceutical legislation will also help streamline procedures to quicken supply chains. Approval times for medicines are set to be cut by an average 30 days in Europe following an agreement by the European Commission, European Parliament and the Council of the European Union to update 20-year-old pharmaceutical legislation. In a statement also published on 11 December 2025, the European Medicines Agency (EMA) said: “This represents the most significant overhaul of the regulatory framework in over two decades and is a once-in-a-generation opportunity to reshape medicines regulation in the EU.”. Commenting on the latest legislation update, Emer Cooke, executive director of the EMA, said: “By simplifying procedures, embracing digitalisation and rationalising our use of scientific resources, we will be better positioned to support innovation and ensure that promising new treatments reach patients faster. In the UK, the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) has eliminated backlogs in approvals for new medicines.

title: EU proposal would simplify Medical Device Regulation - MedTech Dive
snippet: # EU proposal would simplify Medical Device Regulation. If finalized, the changes would reduce the scope of AI regulations for medical devices and include more provisions for rare disease treatments. The proposals, which were praised by industry group MedTech Europe, aim to simplify the regulations by reducing administrative burdens, encouraging coordination among regulatory bodies and including more provisions for devices intended to treat rare diseases. According to the text, transitioning to MDR and IVDR from the previous regulatory framework has "led to the discontinuation of certain devices intended for small groups of patients, as the costs for the transition made it economically difficult for manufacturers to undertake conformity assessment.”. “The proposed introduction of pathways for breakthrough innovation and orphan devices is critical for more rapid access to needed, safe and effective technologies,” MedTech Europe wrote. The European Parliament in 2024 called for reforms to MDR and IVDR, and MedTech Europe called for regulatory changes by early 2026. * EU proposal would simplify Medical Device Regulation.

title: Accelerating Biocontrol Authorization is Essential for Sustainable Agriculture in Europe - Euractiv
snippet: # Accelerating Biocontrol Authorization is Essential for Sustainable Agriculture in Europe. The planned simplification package communicated in the European Commissions Vision for Agriculture is a legislative proposal planned for the end of 2025 to accelerate biocontrol authorization, promising a regulatory framework that truly supports Europe’s transition to sustainable agriculture. Allowing Member States to grant provisional authorizations for new innovative biocontrol active substances would speed responsible market access without compromising safety. Today more than half of Member State resources is spent on re-registration, which for biocontrol rarely results in a change in the risk assessment, but takes 4-5 years of time and resources that could be spent on evaluating applications for new innovations in biocontrol. The simplification package has the potential to transform Europe’s biocontrol landscape—boosting innovation, accelerating access, and ensuring that regulatory rigor is matched by regulatory efficiency. Europe has a rare opportunity to make biocontrol a true cornerstone of sustainable agriculture.

title: AI regulation globally: four approaches shaping the regulatory landscape: By Sam Green - Finextra Research
snippet: It allows domain-expert regulators to oversee the use of AI in their respective sectors, avoids the burdens that the EU AI Act’s approach imposes on regulated entities, and minimises the risk of rapidly becoming outdated as the technology evolves. *   **Utah**: The Artificial Intelligence Policy Act (SB149), in force since May 2024, requires transparency when generative AI is used in consumer-facing interactions, particularly in regulated or high-risk contexts. Instead, it has developed a supervisory-led approach, most notably through proposals by theMonetary Authority of Singapore (MAS)for AI risk management guidelines for financial institutions. Unlike the EU AI Act’s predefined risk categories, MAS is proposing a dynamic, context-sensitive approach, assessing AI risk based on impact, complexity, and the degree to which systems are embedded in critical business workflows. The EU has anchored oversight in statute and ex ante risk classification; the UK has prioritised sector-led flexibility; the US is evolving through fragmented, state-driven intervention; and Singapore is advancing a supervisory model centred on continuous risk assessment and governance capability - leaving firms to translate fundamentally different regulatory models into operational practice.

title: SEC flags Bitcoin miner hosting services as subject to securities laws - TradingView — Track All Markets
snippet: The SEC sued the Bitcoin (BTC) mining company VBit and its founder, Danh Vo, in a Delaware federal court on Wednesday, accusing them of fraud and misappropriating around $48 million in investor funds between 2018 and 2022 by selling a greater number of hosting agreements than there were mining rigs. The SEC claimed that Vo’s Bitcoin mining hosting operation fell far short of standard industry practices, with investors unable to track their rigs, and the company retaining full operational control. VBit also directed hashrate into a mining pool under its control, which appeared to be a defining factor in the SEC’s classification of VBit’s hosted Bitcoin mining agreement as a security. **SEC’s view shouldn’t impact hosted Bitcoin mining industry**. The SEC’s view that hosted Bitcoin mining can constitute a security is one of the most notable classifications under the Trump administration, which has positioned the SEC to be more supportive of the industry.

title: EverValue Coin (EVA) consolidates an economic model with growing Bitcoin backing - markets.businessinsider.com
snippet: In this context, EverValue Coin (EVA) has stood out over the past year by developing an economic model supported by Bitcoin mining and on-chain transparency. EVA is a token built on the Arbitrum network, whose structural value is backed by Bitcoin deposited in an immutable and audited smart contract known as the Burn Vault. Over the past twelve months, the project expanded its mining operations, strengthened its Bitcoin backing, and increased its presence across exchanges, events, and institutional initiatives. The vault receives recurring Bitcoin inflows generated by the project’s own mining operations, which are converted into wBTC and deposited directly into the smart contract in a public and verifiable manner — on a daily basis. In response, EverValue is preparing a new backing vault that will allow tokens to be redeemed at a price much closer to market value — increasing daily in parallel with the core Burn Vault, its original version. The project is supported by real-world infrastructure, including Bitcoin mining operations, and utilizes smart contracts to manage backing, supply mechanics, and liquidity in a verifiable manner.

title: Govt. Approves INR 7,280 Crore Scheme to Promote Sintered Rare Earth Magnet Manufacturing - Energetica India Magazine
snippet: Approves INR 7,280 Crore Scheme to Promote Sintered Rare Earth Magnet Manufacturing. Approves INR 7,280 Crore Scheme to Promote Sintered Rare Earth Magnet Manufacturing. Government has approved INR 7,280 crore scheme to boost domestic manufacturing of sintered rare earth permanent magnets and strengthen India’s industrial and strategic supply chains. The Government has sanctioned a INR 7,280 crore scheme to develop a domestic manufacturing ecosystem for NdFeB (neodymium-iron-boron) rare earth permanent magnets (REPM) in India. The scheme aims to create a fully integrated value chain in India, from rare earth oxide (NdPr oxide) to metals, alloys, and finished magnets, to reduce dependence on imports and strengthen the country’s strategic and industrial capacities. IREL has a production capacity of 400 MTPA of NdPr oxide, sufficient to support about 1,200 MTPA of integrated NdFeB magnet production, and holds an additional stock of 500 metric tons of NdPr oxide, allowing India to support approximately 1,500 MTPA of REPM production. Rare earth magnets manufacturing India.

title: Rare Earth Permanent Magnets Manufacturing Incentive Scheme Announced by Ministry of Heavy Industries to Boost - CNBC TV18
snippet: HomeEconomy NewsCentre notifies ₹7,280 crore scheme to boost domestic rare earth magnets production. # Centre notifies ₹7,280 crore scheme to boost domestic rare earth magnets production. ## India launches a ₹7,280 crore scheme to boost NdFeB magnet production, offering incentives and subsidies, with IREL supplying NdPr oxide for key sectors. The Ministry of Heavy Industries has notified a new ₹7,280 crore incentive scheme to promote domestic manufacturing of rare earth permanent magnets, a critical input for electric vehicles, wind turbines, electronics and defence equipment, as India looks to reduce its dependence on imports. Under the scheme, manufacturers of sintered NdFeB (neodymium-iron-boron) magnets will be eligible for sales-linked incentives up to ₹2,150 per kg. To qualify, companies will need to make a minimum investment of ₹300 crore to ₹600 crore, based on the capacity they plan to build. * 600 MTPA capacity: Minimum net worth of ₹180 crore. * 700 - 800 MTPA capacity: Minimum net worth of ₹245 crore.

title: Centre notifies rare earth magnet scheme - financialexpress.com
snippet: The scheme targets the creation of a domestic manufacturing capacity of 6,000 metric tonnes per annum (MTPA) of sintered Neodymium-Iron-Boron (NdFeB) magnets, a key input for sectors such as electronics, electric vehicles, aerospace and renewable energy. Manufacturers will be eligible for a sales-linked incentive capped at 40 per cent of their net sales turnover, along with a capital subsidy covering 15 per cent of eligible investments. Sales-linked incentives will be disbursed only after the commissioning of manufacturing capacity and will be capped in the range of ₹645 crore to ₹1,290 crore. The minimum expenditure towards eligible investment under the scheme has been set between ₹300 crore and ₹600 crore. A bidder applying for 600 TPA capacity must have a minimum net worth of ₹180 crore. For capacities of 700-800 TPA, the minimum net worth requirement is ₹245 crore, while bidders seeking 900-1,000 TPA capacity must have a net worth of at least ₹310 crore. For applications covering 1,100-1,200 TPA capacity, the minimum net worth requirement is ₹375 crore.

title: Rare earth element technologies developed at Mines licensed by Australian mining company - Mines Newsroom
snippet: Colorado School of Mines has entered an exclusive worldwide licensing agreement with Australian-headquartered mining company Bayan Mining and Minerals Limited and its U.S. subsidiary for a suite of four patented rare earth element processing technologies. The licensed technologies, developed by researchers in the Kroll Institute for Extractive Metallurgy (KIEM) at Mines, target higher rare earth element recovery and lower processing costs from bastnaesite-dominant ores, a valuable source of light rare earth elements (LREE) like cerium, lanthanum, neodymium and praseodymium, as well as less studied minerals like ancylite. Bayan is seeking to secure a strategic position at the forefront of rare earth processing innovation within the U.S., and this exclusive license agreement provides full rights to deploy, enhance and sub-license the Mines-developed technologies worldwide. “Mid-stream processing is the critical bridge between mining and manufacturing, where value is created and innovations in efficiency, cost reduction and environmental performance determine whether critical minerals can reliably support modern technologies and national priorities.”. Bayan Mining and Minerals Ltd operates in the mining industry, focusing on critical minerals, particularly rare earth elements (REE).

Apatite occurs extensively across the sampled intervals and serves as the primary carrier of rare earths – an uncommon mineralisation style globally. title: ABx confirms rare earth heap leach potential - Mining.com.au
snippet: * ABx confirms rare earth heap leach potential. # ABx confirms rare earth heap leach potential. ABx Group (ASX:ABX) has reported preliminary results from two rare earth column leach tests conducted by the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) on 26kg bulk samples. Following 17 days of testing, the first column test achieved 81% rare earths extraction, including 76% dysprosium and 79% terbium. Previous results from short-duration leaching tests of bulk samples from Deep Leads consistently achieved 65-75% extraction. The full column leach tests will be complete before the end of December and unloaded in early January, with the remaining solutions to be analysed for final rare earth recoveries, impurity levels, and to assess leaching kinetics. ABx Group is focused on delivering rare earths, bauxite, and industrial chemicals essential for a clean energy transition. title: Did GM Just Troll Ford? - CleanTechnica
snippet: But I did wonder, did someone at GM say, “*hey, let’s do a little thing on how EVs work to show that we know how to do EVs even if Ford doesn’t.*” That would be a nice little bit of trolling. Electric vehicles are General Motors’ “North Star.” Experience the smooth, quiet, near-instant power of an EV for yourself, and you’ll understand why. Every GM EV uses drive units – which consist of motor, inverter, and gearset – to turn electricity from the battery into motion. In an EV, the battery stores energy as direct current (DC), but the motor needs alternating current (AC) to generate rotation. Most GM drive units use permanent magnet propulsion, meaning the motor’s “instruments” are magnets. Electric motors use these magnetic forces to turn electrical energy into rotational force, called torque. In an EV, you don’t need a separate set of gears to make the car back up — when you shift into Reverse, the EV’s computer simply tells the drive unit to spin in the opposite direction.

title: Tesla Wins Final Court Fight Over Elon Musk’s Pay Package - The Wall Street Journal
snippet:
This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. Distribution and use of this material are governed by

## Delaware’s Supreme Court reversed lower court’s decision to cancel the CEO’s 2018 pay package

Tesla TSLA -0.45%decrease; red down pointing triangle won its fight over a record-breaking pay package for Chief Executive Elon Musk that was approved by shareholders in 2018.

3. Account [...] Spencer Penn worked at Tesla and Waymo before he founded LightSource, an AI-powered procurement startup.

While Tesla was more horizontal with a "king" on top, Waymo was more vertically organized, Penn said.

Penn shared his leadership lessons from the two companies with Business Insider.

This as-told-to essay is based on a conversation with Spencer Penn, the 33-year-old founder of LightSource, who lives in San Francisco. It's been edited for length and clarity. [...] I moved to California 10 years ago, back when Tesla was a boutique car business. We were making 1,000 vehicles a week.

My friends and family were telling me it was a big career mistake to work at Tesla. They said it would never be someone's main car, that it's a tech toy, that it's an iPad with wheels on it. But I was just excited to see what this Elon guy was up to.

He previously worked at The Verge, where he also covered consumer technology, hosted many short- and long-form videos, performed product and editorial photography, and once [...] After years of back-and-forth, including a trial where Musk testified, the Chancery Court judge overseeing the case agreed with the plaintiff and initially struck down the pay package in January 2024. Tesla held a vote at its annual meeting in 2024 where shareholders “re-approved” the package, but the judge confirmed her decision in December 2024. Tesla appealed soon after.

title: Tesla shares jump as Musk confirms driverless robotaxi testing - Reuters
snippet: # Tesla shares jump as Musk confirms driverless robotaxi testing. Dec 15 (Reuters) - Tesla (TSLA.O), opens new tab shares hit their highest in nearly a year on Monday after CEO Elon Musk said the electric-vehicle maker was testing its robotaxis without safety monitors in the front passenger seat. While much of Tesla's $1.53 trillion valuation — the highest of any automaker globally — is tied to investor optimism around its self-driving technology and humanoid robot ambitions, the bulk of its revenue and profit still comes from selling electric vehicles. "The news Tesla is testing robotaxis without the safety monitors is in line with our expectations that the company is making progress in its testing, in line with management's statements during the third quarter earnings call," said Seth Goldstein, senior equity analyst at Morningstar. Tesla reported the testing progress as FSD version 14 continues rolling out to more vehicles in its fleet.

title: Which is better? New Tesla Model Y vs Skoda Enyaq - Yahoo! Autos
snippet: New Tesla Model Y vs Skoda Enyaq. The Model Y, Tesla’s best-selling car in Europe until recently, has now received a facelift designed to distinguish it from earlier versions clearly. At low speeds, both cars ride firmly, though the updated Model Y is more comfortable than before. On paper, the Model Y offers a longer driving range than the Enyaq. Tesla advertises a range of 629km (391 miles) in long-range, rear-wheel drive versions, which is up near the top of the class. Both the Tesla Model Y and Skoda Enyaq are practical, spacious and capable electric family cars with more than enough performance for everyday use. The Enyaq impresses with its comfort, refinement and thoughtful details, while the Model Y counters with stronger performance, better efficiency and competitive running costs. The margins are small, but taken as a whole, the updated Tesla Model Y just comes out on top. Tesla Model Y Skoda Enyaq Coupé.

title: Driverless Tesla spotted on Austin streets, drawing fresh focus on robotaxis - Ynetnews
snippet: ## A Tesla Model Y was seen driving without a driver in Austin and retweeted by Tesla AI chief Ashok Elluswamy, as Wall Street projects autonomous ride-hailing could become a trillion-dollar market. A Tesla Model Y was spotted driving through public streets in Austin, Texas, with no visible driver or passengers, a moment that quickly went viral and reignited debate over how close fully autonomous vehicles are to mainstream use. The post gained further attention after it was retweeted by Ashok Elluswamy, Tesla’s head of AI and Autopilot, who wrote: “And so it begins.” The comment was widely interpreted as a signal of Tesla’s confidence in its autonomous driving progress. Bank of America analysts estimate that if self-driving vehicles reduce costs to levels closer to owning a private car, autonomous ride-hailing could account for up to 20 percent of all miles driven over the next 15 years.

title: What Investors Continue To Get Wrong About Tesla - Forbes
snippet: This past weekend, something happened in Austin that should get every Tesla investor's attention: Model Y vehicles started driving themselves through city streets with nobody inside. Tesla's Austin robotaxi fleet currently consists of only about 25-30 vehicles. Beyond robotaxis, Tesla is eyeing the $900+ billion U.S. trucking industry with its Semi truck, which is expected to begin volume production in 2026. Tesla's empty cars driving through Austin represent either the beginning of a transportation revolution or an expensive science experiment that's years behind better-funded competitors. If you're buying Tesla today, you're not betting on car sales - you're betting that the company can turn its fleet of vehicles into a platform for AI-powered services that generate recurring revenue for decades. Watch for three things in 2026: whether Tesla can scale its Austin robotaxi fleet from dozens to thousands of vehicles, whether the Semi truck enters volume production as promised, and whether Full Self-Driving subscriptions become a meaningful revenue stream.

title: Ford recalls nearly 273,000 vehicles over rollaway risk - CBS News
snippet: # Ford recalls nearly 273,000 vehicles over rollaway risk. Mary Cunningham is a reporter for CBS MoneyWatch. She previously worked at "60 Minutes," CBSNews.com and CBS News 24/7 as part of the CBS News Associate Program. Add CBS News on Google. Ford Motor is recalling nearly 273,000 vehicles due to an issue with the parking function that could cause cars to roll away, increasing the risk of a crash, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA). The recall affects certain F-150 Lightning BEV pickup trucks with model years 2022-2026; Mustang Mach-E cars with model years 2024-2026; and Maverick pickups with model years 2025-2026. The integrated parking module in those vehicles may fail to lock into park when drivers shift into that gear, NHTSA said in a notice. Ford's number for this recall is 25C69. Ford recalled more than 197,000 Mustang Mach-E vehicles in June over a separate problem with the cars' door latches. #### CBS News 24/7.

title: Volkswagen reveals self-driving rival to Tesla Cybercab - Torquecafe.com
snippet: # Volkswagen reveals self-driving rival to Tesla Cybercab. Tesla revolutionised semi-autonomous driving technology with its so-called Full Self-Driving system, a more advanced version of which will soon end up in its fleet of Cybercab robotaxis in the US. Volkswagen has announced it’s currently in the next stage of testing its Gen.Urban self-driving research vehicle, having previously quietly rolled the car out for “intensive trials”. Now capable of driving itself on the streets of Wolfsburg where Volkswagen is headquartered, Gen.Urban remains the centre of a research project for now, however the German car giant is aiming to “explore how passengers experience riding in a self-driving vehicle without a traditional steering wheel or pedals”. “With our Gen.Urban research vehicle, we want to understand exactly how passengers experience autonomous driving. Like other self-driving cars such as Tesla’s Cybercab and even the fleet of Jaguar I-Pace-based Waymos in the US, Volkswagen says customers using Gen.Urban can make adjustments to the cabin temperature and ambient lighting prior to its arrival. ### Volkswagen reveals self-driving rival to Tesla Cybercab.

title: China Approves First Level‑3 Self‑Driving Cars - StratNews Global
snippet: The auto industry has defined five levels of autonomous driving, from cruise control at level one to fully self-driving cars at level five, and level three allows drivers to take their eyes and hands off the road in certain situations. On Monday, China’s industry regulator authorized two domestically made cars equipped with level-3 autonomous driving technology, marking the first time such vehicles have been officially approved for nationwide mass adoption. The auto industry has defined five levels of autonomous driving, from cruise control at level one to fully self-driving cars at level five, and level three allows drivers to take their eyes and hands off the road in certain situations. Last year, China lined up nine automakers for public tests to advance the adoption of self-driving cars. Autonomous driving developers such as Pony AI and WeRide have been testing their level-4 cars with licenses granted by local governments across China. Tesla’s Full Self-Driving, a level-2 driver assistance system, has been partially approved in China since February and falls short of its capabilities in the United States.
